review.title: Variance Based Moving K-Means Algorithm
review.abstract: Clustering is a useful data exploratory method with its wide applicability in multiple fields. However, data clustering greatly relies on initialization of cluster centers that can result in large intra-cluster variance and dead centers, therefore leading to sub-optimal solutions. This paper proposes a novel variance based version of the conventional Moving K-Means (MKM) algorithm called Variance Based Moving K-Means (VMKM) that can partition data into optimal homogeneous clusters, irrespective of cluster initialization. The algorithm utilizes a novel distance metric and a unique data element selection criteria to transfer the selected elements between clusters to achieve low intra-cluster variance and subsequently avoid dead centers. Quantitative and qualitative comparison with various clustering techniques is performed on four datasets selected from image processing, bioinformatics, remote sensing and the stock market respectively. An extensive analysis highlights the superior performance of the proposed method over other techniques.
histories: Accepted at the 7th IEEE International Advance Computing Conference (IACC-2017)

metadata.title: Variance Based Moving K-Means Algorithm

sections.text: This year is the highest in the history of the country.

sections.heading: B. Bioinformatics
sections.text: In this experiment, we aim to group similar patterns using the proposed VMKM algorithm in the yeast bioinformatics dataset [7]. The dataset contains 6400 gene expression values of Saccharomyces cerevisiae that were recorded during the metabolic change from fermentation to respiration using DNA microarrays. As the dataset is large and consists of genes with low expression values, we trim the dataset by retaining only those genes that exhibit drastically altered expression profiles during the diauxic shift. The dataset is further refined by assigning one to the series in which the yeast values have a variance greater than the 10th percentile, while the values below that value are represented by zero. The VMKM algorithm is used to group the data into sixteen gene expression profiles. The quantitative results for the gene table for the classification are measured on the basis of the MSE.

sections.heading: C. Remote Sensing
sections.text: The remote sensing data set used is a four-band multi-spectral image of the district of Mysore in the southern part of India [13]. The image has dimensions of 1375 x 5929 pixels, an area of 2.748 km x 7.973 km and a resolution of 2.4 m. The image maps information on four crop classes (sugarcane, ragi, brushwood and mulberry) from different fields in the area. Multiple images facilitate the classification and identification of plants by taking into account changes in reflection as a function of the crop type. This information allows individuals to track the positive and negative dynamics of crop development as well as several natural processes such as erosion, soil composition and vegetation conditions that can help government officials plan efficient land use and plant management. In this study, we aim to divide the satellite image into four crop classes, using the proposed VMKM cluster method, which is similar to the quantitative results proposed for the seven plant classification table with MSE being the most comparable to the MSE.

sections.heading: D. Stock Market
sections.text: The VMKM algorithm is used to cluster all stocks that have a greater variance in five clusters (K = 5) and therefore have a better chance of a positive return. Quantitative results for stock identification are presented in Table I. The proposed method is also compared with seven other popular cluster methods. It is shown in the table that K-Means produces the highest MSE, followed by AMKM, MKM, EMKM-2, EMKM1 and FCM. The best cluster is provided by Kernel K-Means and VMKM with similarly low MSE.Fig.4. Graph compares the average MSE of different algorithms applied to the master data set.

sections.heading: E. Comparison of VMKM with Kernel K Means
sections.text: Table I shows that kernel K-Means performs almost as well for bioinformatics, remote sensing and stock market as the proposed algorithm. Despite the comparable performance of kernel K-Means for VMKM and the ability to separate non-linear data, it has some obvious disadvantages. The former is a complex algorithm with great time complexity. In addition, knowledge of the kernel K-Means to be used for data separation is indispensable before applying kernel K-Means. VMKM has no such limitations, making it a superior choice compared to kernel K-Means.IV. CONCLUSS This paper presents a new version of the MKM algorithm called Variance based Moving K-Means (VMKM). The process of assigning and subsequently transferring data elements takes into account the cluster variance and correlation of the data company adjacent to the parent company as well as the cluster.

However, data clustering greatly relies on initialization of cluster centers that can result in large intra-cluster variance and dead centers, therefore leading to sub-optimal solutions.
